answers.answer: It could. I had a small drink of soda and a piece of bread 5 hours before my 1hr test and I failed it but didnt eat or drink anything for 12hrs with my 3hr test and passed with flying colors
Thank you....How many weeks were u with ur first one?
The one hour test?

I ate a bagel before mine and everything came back great...i did tell my obgyn that I ate the bagel before the drink and he told me not worry and he would mark it in my chart and if something came back funny he would have me do the 3 hr test...so I think u should be fine...but def let ur ob know u did eat something small before it...
My doc told me you can eat up until its time to drink that nastu stuff and they have said it doesnt effect the results anymore...i dont go in for my for another couple weeks so hopefully shes right.
Thanks I hope it doesn't tamper with my results its so many rules to pregnancy these days

As some one who had gestational diabetes last pregnancy..I urge you to contact your doc.and tell them the truth. If they say you're nit supposed to eat its for good reason. Trust me gestational diabetes is serious and you should ask.for a re test.

Yeah I fail my 1 HR. Test too because I ate some melon before the test but the doc. Never told me I was not allow to eat :(  and then told me that I probably already had diabetes because I was overweight and Hispanic!! O and the nurse had told me I had fail my test by one point well my doc. Lie and said I fail by 11 points that's why I already had diabetes :( well I did my 3 HR test and  pass!! And now I only see my midwife I ask to not see her anymore since she was giving me inaccurate information!!
My dr said you should eat before your test just not anything sweet...she said fasting can cause a false positive

If u ate and still passed I wouldn't worry cause between the sugary drink and the yogurt and ur suger still wasnt high I would think ur fine. U should probably mention it to be safe just in case u have some symptoms later they will pick up on what it is.
I ate half a bagel and had to go back to do the 3 hour test. Lol
I'm a little nervous now...I suppose ill be calling my doctor tomorrow thank u ladies

Herr fasting is essential to the test. 10pm to 9am. This will reveal how the sugars are in the body without eating. This is especially important in the three hour as they re test your bloods after the drink to see how your body has reacted. If anything eating would cause a false positive. It's not just sweets etc that has sugar in. White bread..white pasta...yoghurt..fruit etc all have sugar in. Some places you are allowed to eat but it varies everywhere so I would def tell your doc. Hope this helped ,

Well I'm just saying what my Dr said ok....and my Dr is a wonderful one and I'm sure she wouldn't tell me to eat unless she was sure of herself...I know how bad gestional diabetes can be because I had it with my son...but because I was able to control it strictly by diet and never really had any problems with it ever being high my Dr believes that it WAS a false positive from eating so please refrain from trying to tell me that my Dr is wrong

*here fasting is essential..     argell there's no need to get  so angry and defensive. I had gd with my daughter too and had to do diet control and .metformin. some places don't require fasting. Some do. If you are told to fast then yes you should and eating can mess the results up. Please calm down.
I also said above some places are allowed to eat. But she stated she wasn't supposed to..

I'm not getting angry but you sit there and act as if I told her that fasting is bad when I clearly stated my Dr informed me yes I'm going to defend myself....I never said I am the one that knows it because I surely didn't go to school for 8+ years and earn a degree but when my Dr tells me and I was merely relaying what she said and you jump in and say I'm wrong than there is an issue...

Never Said you were wrong. I Said she shouldn't eat on a test she is supposed to fast for. That causes false positives. If she was told to eat yes eat but she wasnt supposed to eat. Not her fault as she didn't know. But there are reasons for fasting tests. Please stop feeling like I jumped in and attacked you. I was trying to help and state that if she was tested and ate during a fasting test it can cause false or unreliable results.

I suppose this community is meant to help pregnant women by supporting them with your opinion and experience and not a place to take up things too seriously and personally.From what I have been reading, it is not what the other person says, but what your ATTITUDE is that matters.No harm intended pls.

question: I ate a. Little bit of yogurt before my diabetes test and I'm 26 weeks pregnant I wasn't aware that i wasn't suppose to eat anything...should i be as worried as I am? Will the yogurt effect my results?
